text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

Each year, eight billion
hours are spent braiding hair.

It's not just a waste of time,
but it represents billions

of dollars of lost
value for people,

mainly Black women, who
get their hair braided.

And we've spoken to
hundreds of them.

Braiding is time consuming,
it takes six hours.

It's expensive,
costing $200 to $300,

and you repeat it
every eight weeks.

And it's painful
for stylists who

get arthritis and permanent
nerve damage in their 30s.

That's why we're building HALO,
a patent-pending automated hair
braider that saves time.

Stylists start the
braid, HALO finishes it,

and we reduce braiding time
from six hours to minutes.

We make braiding
painless and consistent,

and we allow a stylist
to triple their business,

giving us an $11
billion opportunity
to transform braiding.

I'm Yinka, the
founder of HALO Braid.

I'm a second time
hardware founder,

mechanical engineer with
six products on the market
and four patents.

And most importantly, I've
worn braids all my life.

And during the lockdown, I
tried braiding my own hair

for the first time, and
it took me four days.

Our team of engineers
and marketers

have experience building and
scaling consumer hardware
products.

We followed a pattern,
we've built a prototype,

and we're launching to 20 salons
this summer who have signed up
to be paying customers.

Then early next year, we're
launching into a waitlist
of over 400 stylists.

We're excited to bring
much needed innovation

to an overlooked
industry that hasn't
changed in thousands of years.
We're HALO braid.

Help us change the
future of braiding.
Thank you.
[CHEERING AND APPLAUSE]
